question_text: A 29-year-old man returns for evaluation of recurrent painful oral ulcers, knee pain, and fever. He was diagnosed with his second episode of uveitis 1 week ago. For diagnostic purposes, his arm was pricked with a sterile needle 48 hours ago; the results are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Behçet syndrome (Option A), an inflammatory systemic disease associated with pathergy (an inflammatory response, such as a papule, to skin prick with a sterile needle). Behçet syndrome is characterized by recurrent, painful oral and genital mucosal ulcerations and inflammatory eye disease (panuveitis, retinal vasculitis). Pathergy strongly suggests Behçet syndrome; however, results of pathergy tests are often negative, particularly in nonendemic areas.
